channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Ministers prepare for worst in gas price crisis
item.description: Business minister Paul Scully says the government needs to plan for a lengthy spell of high gas prices.

item.title: Police investigating if stranger killed Sabina Nessa
item.description: The teacher had been on her way to meet a friend but was killed shortly after leaving home.

item.title: BP closes some sites due to lorry driver shortage
item.description: The oil firm said only "a handful" of sites are affected by the fuel supply issues.

item.title: Woman with Down's loses abortion law fight
item.description: Heidi Crowter says the current law on abortion for foetuses with the condition does not respect her life.

item.title: Linda Evangelista says she was left 'deformed' by cosmetic procedure
item.description: The star says she has become "a recluse" after an adverse reaction to a fat reduction procedure.

item.title: Killamarsh: Father's tribute to daughter killed at sleepover
item.description: Connie Gent was one of three children who were killed at a Derbyshire home.

item.title: US Haiti envoy quits over 'inhumane' deportations
item.description: Daniel Foote says US policy on Haiti is "flawed" and sending migrants back is "counterproductive".

item.title: Grenfell: No action over 2009 cladding warning, inquiry told
item.description: The London Fire Brigade asked the government to warn of the risks seven years before the Grenfell fire.

item.title: NHS Wales: Waiting times and A&E at worst performance level
item.description: Numbers waiting for hospital treatment and A&E waiting times are the worst on record.

item.title: Inflation: Bank of England says price rises to top 4% by year-end
item.description: The Bank keeps interest rates at 0.1% and says there are signs of slowing economic growth.

item.title: Former Labour MP Keith Vaz faces Parliament pass ban over bullying staff member
item.description: The ex-Labour MP should be ashamed of his behaviour, a report says, but he rejects the ruling.

item.title: EU rules to force USB-C chargers for all phones
item.description: Manufacturers could be forced to change devices to a uniform charging system.

item.title: The epic adventures of the Gilgamesh Dream tablet
item.description: How an ancient story of a superhuman god ended up in all sorts of unexpected places.

item.title: Covid: How can missing five million be persuaded to have the jab?
item.description: Headlines have focused on teenagers and booster doses - but millions still haven't had a first jab.

item.title: 'Side-eyeing Chloe' Clem to sell iconic meme as NFT
item.description: The image of Chloe Clem could fetch her tens of thousands of dollars at auction.

item.title: Covid-19: New allergic reactions to hair dye reported
item.description: Scientists at Imperial College London are now researching a link between Covid-19 and new allergies.

item.title: Angela Merkel: What will Germans miss about the chancellor?
item.description: BBC Europe editor Katya Adler takes a road trip to find out how Germans will remember their chancellor.

item.title: Saoirse Ronan: Macbeth and Lady Macbeth are like Kim and Kanye
item.description: The actress says Kim Kardashian has inspired the "uncharted territory" of her first UK stage role.

item.title: La Palma volcano lava engulfs homes and swimming pools
item.description: Molten rock from the erupting Cumbre Vieja volcano is destroying hundreds of buildings.

item.title: Is 'the worst cold ever' going around?
item.description: As more people mix again, the common cold is back - and leaving people floored.

item.title: Covid debt: A baby, job loss - and now eviction
item.description: Tenants are being evicted due to rent arrears built up during the pandemic, an investigation finds.

item.title: Boris Johnson at the UN fact-checked
item.description: The prime minister's speech focused largely on climate change and the UK's role in tackling it.

item.title: Angela Merkel: Four expert verdicts on a contested legacy
item.description: When the German chancellor steps down, how will history remember her? Four experts have their say.

item.title: 'Giving birth left me needing a colostomy bag'
item.description: Former triathlete Kayleigh Adams endured a fourth-degree tear that led to her needing a colostomy bag.

item.title: The edible insects coming to a supermarket near you
item.description: A number of firms are now farming locusts and mealworms for human consumption.

item.title: Changing China: Xi Jinping's effort to return to socialism
item.description: China has not been very socialist for years, but the Communist Party looks set to change that.

item.title: Claims on pay, tax and the cost of living checked
item.description: Deputy prime minister Dominic Raab took Prime Minister's Questions on Wednesday.

item.title: Johnson and Biden: Contrasting characters do business
item.description: No major gaffes and progress on climate change on PM's US trip but a trade deal remains a distant prospect.

item.title: I doubt I'd have taken Derby job if I'd known about crisis but I won't walk away - Rooney
item.description: Wayne Rooney reiterates he will not quit Derby County despite the club being placed in administration.

item.title: Homecoming for Raducanu to be shown live on BBC
item.description: A homecoming event for US Open champion Emma Raducanu will be shown live on the BBC on Friday.

item.title: After three straight defeats, what will Guardiola try next against Tuchel?
item.description: Chelsea boss Thomas Tuchel has beaten Pep Guardiola in three successive matches - so what will the Manchester City manager do on Saturday?

item.title: 'I am very relaxed' - Verstappen rejects Hamilton's claim over title pressure
item.description: Max Verstappen rejects Lewis Hamilton's suggestion that he could be feeling the pressure of their title fight.

item.title: Rugby World Cup winner Thompson to donate brain for CTE research
item.description: Rugby World Cup winner Steve Thompson, who was diagnosed with dementia aged 42, will donate his brain to scientists researching brain trauma.

item.title: What can I do if my energy supplier goes bust?
item.description: Nearly 1.5 million customers have seen their energy firm collapse amid soaring gas prices.

item.title: Gas prices: 'I'm just watching the meter go up'
item.description: Customers caught in the middle of the energy price crisis face higher bills but are told not to panic.

item.title: Gas prices: Why are they so high and what is the energy price cap?’
item.description: Householders face a rise in energy bills - as well as the possibility their supplier could go bust.

item.title: Why is there a CO2 shortage and how will it hit food supplies?
item.description: The UK's food industry has been told it must pay five times more for carbon dioxide in future.

item.title: Where does the UK get its gas and is it facing a shortage this winter?
item.description: A surge in gas prices has prompted fears of hard times ahead - but how bad could it get?

item.title: The torso in the Thames: A 20-year mystery
item.description: Twenty years ago, a young African boy was murdered and his torso was dumped in the Thames. It's the longest unsolved child murder case in the recent history of the Metropolitan Police.

item.title: Paul Rusesabagina: From Hotel Rwanda hero to convicted terrorist
item.description: Paul Rusesabagina, who was portrayed in Hotel Rwanda, has gone from national hero to enemy of the state.

item.title: Fake Paralympians boss: 'I didn't know about cheating'
item.description: The man fined for sending non-disabled athletes to the Sydney Paralympics breaks his silence.

item.title: Muriel Gardiner: The heiress who saved countless lives
item.description: Muriel Gardiner's courage fighting fascism in Austria inspired an Oscar-winning film. Who was she?

item.title: Hushpuppi - the Instagram influencer and international fraudster
item.description: How Nigerian Ramon Abbas went from a romance scammer to a so-called "Billionaire Gucci Master".
